awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Cognitive Science Principles to Help Children Learn Place Value
awd_abstract_narration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Many children have trouble understanding what multidigit numbers mean and this can lead to long-term problems in mathematics.  Poor place value understanding plagues children from all socioeconomic backgrounds and is not limited to those with learning disabilities. This problem is widespread and pervasive; indeed, perhaps more widespread than currently understood because some tests may overestimate what children know.  The critical skill needed for long-term success, and one not always measured, is called decomposition.  It involves knowing how to break a multi-digit number down into its components by place (ones, tens, hundreds) and interpret its meaning (e.g., 642 = 6 hundreds, 4 tens, and 2 ones). This project will target that crucial skill and test new ways of teaching place value based on principles of analogical reasoning, gleaned from decades of cognitive science research. These new approaches will make place value more transparent by highlighting and aligning its structure across spoken number names, written numerals, and sets of objects. By leveraging these powerful analogical learning mechanisms, it may be possible to teach place value earlier than is typical, so the project will target K-1 students.  If successful, this approach could head off the misconceptions that are currently common among older children. The project will also track children over time, using tests that measure decomposition and other place value concepts to see how they interrelate.  The project's activities have been designed to be inexpensive and fit into everyday educational practice, so that the results may be easily implemented by teachers.

The project will test new instructional approaches designed to help K-1 students comprehend place value. The project is innovative in that it will emphasize the underlying relational structure of place value symbols, and target this structure with instructional materials and techniques drawn from the structure mapping literature. Its theory of action is that instruction which scaffolds structure mapping for place value will better prepare children to face the challenges of advanced operations, such as multi-digit calculation.  The project specifically targets decomposition, as this has been identified as a particular stumbling block for children.  Also, decomposition skill has been linked to better long-term mathematics outcomes. There will be three studies. Study 1 will track the development of place value understanding from kindergarten to 2nd grade, using some measures that clearly require decomposition, and others that are in wide use but may not require decomposition, such as number line estimation and magnitude judgments. The study will show how these measures are related over developmental time, as well as testing whether a firm understanding of decomposition predicts later mathematics learning.  Studies 2 and 3 will use a pretest-training-posttest design to test the efficacy of six structure mapping activities for place value in K-1 students. The training in Study 2 will be focused on one activity for three weeks, whereas the training in Study 3 will include all six activities presented over an entire semester.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on the development of place value concepts, a well-known obstacle in elementary mathematics for many children.  We wanted to understand how children make sense of place value symbols, like written numerals and spoken number names, as well as how children come to understand the concrete meanings of these symbols.  Prior research told us that these concepts can be very challenging for children and deficits in place value knowledge often lead to persistently poor performance in mathematics. However, prior research also told us that very young children are beginning to make sense of place value prior to formal instruction. They seem able to extract some of the patterns in place value symbols just from incidental experiences with large numbers (e.g., they know that numbers with 3 digits stand for greater quantities than numbers with 2 digits).  In this project, we wanted to find out whether there were two different ways of understanding large numbers—(1) an approximate way that young children can access based on partial understanding or rough estimates and (2) a syntactic way that requires precise understanding of place value units and counts of those units that can elude children throughout elementary school.  We also wanted to know how these different understandings might develop relative to each other, and how they contribute to later place value understanding.

 

To find out, we tracked development of place value concepts longitudinally from kindergarten to second grade, and discovered that children show approximate understanding of large number meanings (e.g., knowing that 532 is greater than 235) earlier than they show syntactic understanding (e.g., knowing that the “3” in “532” stands for 3 tens).  We also found evidence that these two understandings are separate but highly correlated constructs in kindergarten, but the two are not separable in first grade. These findings suggest that approximate understandings of large number meanings are somewhat disconnected from syntactic understandings at first, but they eventually merge by first grade.

 

We found further evidence of this pattern using a network analysis approach. Specifically, hildren’s performance on individual place value tasks was less interconnected before the merge than it was after the merge, suggesting that children are learning various aspects of the place value system in a disconnected, piecemeal way, but with instruction, many children successfully integrate these understandings by first grade. A major hub in this reorganization was Transcoding, or children’s ability to translate back and forth between written and verbal number names. The importance of Transcoding indicates that, rather than building place value concepts from mappings between symbols and concrete objects, children are extracting patterns in the formal symbols themselves, similar to what had been reported for preschool children previously.

 

Interestingly, children’s later place value understanding and their calculation skill in second grade were both highly related to their earlier approximate understanding, but not to their syntactic understanding.  This finding suggests that approximate understandings provide a critical foundation for later place value development, and one that may be more accessible to children early on than syntactic understanding. It may be important for teachers to support the development of this approximate foundation in addition to teaching children the syntactic meanings of large number words. Our findings also provide evidence that kindergarten children are actively constructing place value concepts much earlier than they receive formal instruction in school. Children this age would probably be receptive to formal instruction, especially instruction that encourages approximate understanding and carefully builds a bridge to more precise, syntactic concepts.

 

To test this latter idea, we carried out a 12-week training experiment with a group of low- to middle-income kindergarten students.  Half of the children received place value instruction that emphasized the mappings among place value elements (words to symbols, symbols to symbols, symbols to quantities, etc.), and built from simple to more complex mappings. The other half of the children served as controls and completed single-digit calculation practice. At posttest, children in the experimental group showed stronger improvement on place value measures in general, and also showed stronger improvement on syntactic measures in particular, compared to the children in the control group. These findings demonstrate that kindergarten children can benefit from place value instruction, and further, that this instruction may be most effective when place value concepts are broken down into pairwise mappings that emphasize the syntactic structure and correspondences between specific syntactic elements.
